 Question: A researcher wants to determine whether a new study method improves test scores. She randomly assigns 100 high school students to two groups: 50 students use the new study method (treatment group), while 50 students use their regular study methods (control group). After two weeks, all students take the same test, and the treatment group scores 8 points higher on average than the control group. However, when analyzing the data further, the researcher discovers that the treatment group spent an average of 3 more hours studying than the control group during the two-week period. What is the primary flaw in this experimental design, and how could the researcher modify the design to better determine whether the new study method itself (rather than study time) causes improved test scores? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I'm trying to figure out the primary flaw in this experimental design and how to fix it. Let me start by understanding the problem.

The researcher has 100 students, split into two groups of 50. The treatment group uses a new study method, and the control group continues with their regular methods. After two weeks, everyone takes the same test, and the treatment group scores 8 points higher on average. That seems pretty straightforward, but then she notices that the treatment group also spent an average of 3 more hours studying than the control group. Hmm, that adds an extra layer.

So, the main issue here is that both the treatment group's scores and study hours are higher. But does that mean the new study method caused the better scores, or was it just the extra study time? It's like a confounding variable problem. The treatment group's higher study time might be the real reason for their better scores, not necessarily the new method itself.

To address this, the researcher needs to isolate the effect of the new study method. One way to do that is to ensure that both groups study the same amount. If the treatment group is only using the new method but also spending more time, their higher study time could be influencing the results. So, maybe she can make sure both groups study for the same number of hours, but only the treatment group uses the new method. That way, any differences in scores would be more likely due to the method itself.

Alternatively, she could keep the study time the same but have one group use the new method and the other not. But that might not be feasible if the new method is, say, time-consuming. So, maybe she can adjust the study time for the control group to match the treatment group. That way, the only difference is the study method.

Another approach is to randomly assign students to each group, ensuring that any differences in study time are accounted for statistically. But even with randomization, if the treatment group naturally studies more, it could still be a problem. So, perhaps she should measure the study time as a variable and include it in the analysis. That way, she can see if the new method contributes independently to the scores, controlling for study time.

Wait, but in the initial experiment, study time wasn't controlled, so it's a potential confounding variable. The solution should involve either controlling for study time or ensuring that study time is the same across groups so that any score difference can be attributed to the study method.

So, to summarize, the primary flaw is that the treatment group's higher study time could explain their better scores. To fix it, the researcher should either ensure that both groups study the same amount of time, or measure study time and include it in the analysis to control for it.
</think>

The primary flaw in the experimental design is that the treatment group's higher study time could be the cause of their improved test scores, rather than the new study method itself. To isolate the effect of the new method, the researcher should ensure both groups study the same amount of time, making any score differences due to the method alone. This can be achieved by either keeping study time constant or measuring and controlling for it in the analysis.

DONE.
